newsitem.title: BULGARIA: World Bank approves $24.3 million loan to Bulgaria.
newsitem.headline: World Bank approves $24.3 million loan to Bulgaria.

text.p: The World Bank on Wednesday approved $24.3 million loan to Bulgaria to help finance a social insurance administration project, the bank said in a statement.

"The project will support administrative reforms within the government's current social insurance programme by helping to restore the financial strength of its Social Security Fund (SSF)," the statement said.

The project is aimed at assisting the government's reform goals by increasing the operational effciency of the newly formed national Social Security Institute (NSSI) and helping it develop a relationship with the private sector.
It is expected to replace the outdated pension payment system inherited from the communist regime which was completely subsidised by the state.
The dollar equivalent of the highest monthly pension in Bulgaria has melted down to a meagre $25 as a result of inflation and local currency depreciation.

The project due to be implemented over the next four years has a total cost of $32.2 million. Co-financing for the remaining cost will be sought from the European Union Phare programme, USAID, the UK know-How Fund and the NSSI.
The loan will be repayable over 20 years including five years grace.

World Bank commitments to Bulgaria total $893.3 million for tweleve projects since 1990, however less than half has been disbursed because of Bulgaria's delayed implementation of the various project stages.
